explore some of the Common Ground that we have between the web performance and SEO communities while the core web vitals and Page experience signal may very well just be one small part of the ranking Factor there are so many more reasons to care about web performance so what I hope to convince you all of today is that your efforts to improve core web vitals will have an that goes well beyond SEO one of the most illustrative examples I could give you about the value of web performance is the story of project feather in December 2009 Chris Zacharias was working as an engineer at YouTube when he got fed up with how heavy the video watch page had gotten it was over 12200 kilobytes and his goal was to make it under 100 k kilobytes he named the project feather he managed to get most of the way just 98 kilobytes so he finally met his goal and feather was ready for live traffic he wrote up a blog post invited people to start using it and his hypothesis like any reasonable person would expect was that a lighter watch page would lead to faster experiences well about a week later he looked at the data and he was wrong performance had actually gotten worse and as he wrote in a Blog post a few increase from users in places that you would tend to think of as having poorer connectivity or lower-end devices for these users it took extra more like 2 minutes to load this feather watch page which doesn't make sense until you look at their experience on the default watch page which was more like 20 minutes so to them this new experience was so much better proving that performance is relative you can go from having a slow experience to a slightly less slow experience and it would still deliver an immense value to the users so Chris's experiment suffered from sampling bias but but the thing reason why web fonts matter to LCP has to do with the fact that LCP candidates change over time so let's say that your initial LCP is an H1 element and then your super cool custom web font loads a few it's forced by JavaScript code so you've probably heard this referred to as layout thrashing it happens when you modify a Dom element in one part of your code and then you try measuring it in a new part of your code this forces the browser to recalculate all of the styles that are necessary to measure that element and that takes time layout thrashing specifically refers to doing this lots and lots of times over lots of elements causing a chain of expensive rendering work that blocks the main thread so you can break that Chain by reorganizing your code so that your read operations happen before you modify the Dom and then any necessary style recalculation work can happen normally during that presentation phase routine rendering updates do normally occur during the presentation phase side rendering on the initial page load basically has the same issues except its javascript as the intermediary instead of css but the solution in both of these problems is exactly what shopify and equals lazy attribute is lcp poison do not use it it is bad it prevents the browser from eagerly loading the image as early as it could because it first needs to make sure that the image will appear within the viewport and thats not always a quick process maybe the only thing worse than loading equals lazy is the data source attribute because thats an indicator of a custom solution built in javascript and custom solutions are strictly slower than native ones and just to be clear lazy loading is good you should use it but only for content thats below the fold only for content thats not critical the lcp element is by definition critical so it should never be lazy loaded all right so i said this was a twoparter and part two is about prioritization even if the image is discoverable in the html it still might not load as early as it could if there are lots of other higher priority resources on the page chrome assigns images a default priority of low and for the first five images it bumps it up to medium but if you have critical render blocking static content like css javascript fonts those have high priority so you could actually be competing with those resources for network the fetch priority equals high attribute hints to the browser to raise the default priority up to high for these images so it can start loading much sooner all right now were on lcp phase number three resource load duration this one is also only applicable to lcp external resources like images and videos it measures how long the resource takes to load from start to finish and because lcp is measuring the time for an image to appear it wouldnt be unreasonable to think that the images download time is is usually the bottleneck and so when talking about lcp optimization its easy to jump straight into the things that make the image load more quickly and well get to those things in a second but i did want to take this opportunity to share some of the important data that my team has just published recently on the most common lcp bottlenecks in august my colleague brendan kenny published a blog post titled common misconceptions about how to optimize lcp the url is in the corner of the slide i also have a qr code at the end so i think this chart sums it up pretty well let me walk you through it uh for every website in the chrome user experience report we looked at their uh its not yet public we looked at their data on the four lcp phases we aggregated these phase distributions by taking their 75th percentile and then aggregated those stats over all 19 or so million websites in the data set by taking the median value of each of those so so it its a distribution of distributions its kind of mindbending i know uh we did that three times for websites having origin level lcp performance of good needs improvement and poor so you can look at this chart and see which phases sites tend to struggle with the most depending on their lcp performance and interestingly youll find that resource load duration which is represented by the green bar here is always the fastest phase it does gets slower as lcp gets worse but its still far from the bottleneck this data is not saying that you never need to worry about image optimization but maybe what we can take away from this is that images already tend to be optimized well enough that there are other higher priority things that you should be focusing on to improve your lcp the phases that actually seem to be most worrisome at least to me are ttfb in blue and resource load delay in red and thats why all three of the most effective ways to improve lcp so far have been attributed to those phases thats where websites have the most to gain all right so lets say youre one of the few sites that does have terrible resource load duration how do you fix it i think you all have heard these answers a hundred times before so well just breeze right through this so you should try using a modern image format like webp or avif to reduce that file size its going to speed up the download time as a result and and webp tends to be about 30 smaller than comparable jpeg or png images you can also reduce the file size by decreasing the image quality by a lot you dont need to save everything at 100 quality when the human eye cant even tell the difference between that and 80 you can also scale the images down to avoid wasting bites on pixels that never get rendered to the user so even if the image itself is small there are still some things that you can do to shorten the time it takes to go to the server and back the best way to do that is to set a long cache lifetime on your images assuming that they rarely change so then on repeat visits users users can just reuse what theyve already had in cach and that eliminates that network request entirely the other thing that you can do to avoid extra connection setup costs is hosting the image on the same domain as your html resource the same things that slow down ttfb can also slow down this image request you wont need to pay those costs if you use the connections that are already open now were at the fourth and final lcp phase which is element render delay when theres an lcp resource the render delay is measured from the time that the resource is done loading to the time that the resource is finally displayed to the user and when the element is text the render delay starts directly from the ttfb time so as a quick recap of what ive already already mentioned before attempts to minimize the load delay phase might end up shifting the problem to the render delay phase with preloading things like css background images client side rendering or lazy loading can continue to delay that lcp time in the form of render delay no matter how early youve preloaded that image so this is one of the few textbased lcp specific things to know and it has to do with web fonts fonts are external resources web fonts specifically so they show up in the waterfall diagram but theyre not considered to be an lcp resource so the render delay and uh loading duration phases do not actually apply the reason why web fonts matter to lcp has to do with the fact that lcp candidates change over time so lets say that your initial lcp is an h1 element and then your super cool custom web font loads a few seconds later if that web font changes the geometry of the text and bumps the size up just a little bit that is going to be the new lcp candidate several seconds later so it could hurt your performance the best fix for this is to ensure that the system font thats initially shown has a similar size to the custom web font and you can do that with the size adjust css property there are also ways to speed up your web font so that it doesnt impact the lcp time as much so fonts should be cached for a long time a lot of these things are the same things that you can do for images cach them for a long time use better compression use modern image format or font formats like waf 2 its an industry standard and its supported by all modern browsers you should also ideally self host your fonts eliminate that extra connection setup cost there are services like google fonts and they do offer some advanced uh font optimization strategies like subsetting you can say only load the glyphs in this font that are applicable to the characters that i display on this page like latin or whatever you could also subset a font to specific characters if your heading says hello world you can only load those letters h e l l so finally the silent killer of lcp performance is slow javascript execution and we dont usually think of this as a loading performance issue but it definitely could be and im not talking about client side rendering either anything that blocks the main thread for an extended period of time delays the next opportunity to paint and if the lcb image is downloaded and ready to go all of this time will be attributed to its render delay so the solution to this is to break up your long tasks but thats exactly what im about to talk about in the next few slides for inpp so lets get right into it this is core vital number two interaction to next paint inp performs really well on desktop 97 of sites have good inp 76 of sites have good inp on mobile which is a little deceivingly high because uh if you look at only the top 1000 most popular websites this number drops down to 63 now so there is definitely still a lot of room for improvement with inp despite the gains this is what a real interaction looks like in chrome dev tools the top is the interaction track and that shows that the user clicked on something probably uh creating pointer events and below that is all of the main thread activity during the interaction with each entry colorcoded and labeled according to the type of work that it did so again lets simplify this down the top part is the timing of the interaction using box and whiskers representing the three inp phases and the bottom part represents the main thread activity js execution in orange layout work in purple rendering and painting in green all right so using this diagram lets jump into the inp phases the left whisker represents the input delay phase this is what i uh first input delay used to measure thats measured from the moment that the user starts their interaction until the processing for that event can start the central box represents the processing duration this includes all of the time spent handling one or more of the events associated with the interaction like a pointer up and a click event of a tap interaction the right whisker represents the presentation delay this is everything that happens after the events have been processed until that frame is painted to the screen so the number four most effective way to improve core web vitals affects the input delay phase but it could also be just as impactful to the next phase as well and this is to avoid unnecessary javascript you can spend ages shaving milliseconds off of your runtime performance but it would be so much easier if you just throw that code away remember from the project feather story about the tipping point it came when chris was able to replace the flash player with the native html 5 video player and thankfully we dont have to worry about flash plugins anymore but we do have a ton of redundant javascript on our websites for things like libraries and polyfills and just for example css has gotten so incredibly powerful in recent years that things like animations could be done entirely scriptless you dont need to throw everything away either uh even if you just split your javascript bundles into things that you need to use now or use later then you can skip a lot of the time spent parsing and compiling unnecessary scripts number five is yielding to break up long tasks and this is listed under the processing phase but also it could be uh used to improve the input delay phase as well so so whenever javascript is taking a long time to do its work its an opportunity to pause give the browser a chance to paint a frame and then go back and resume your work and this is a strategy known as yielding you do need to be a little bit judicious about when you yield ideally you should do all of the user visible work first and then ensure those changes are displayed to the user and for any followup work thats needed like uh lower priority background tasks maybe logging to analytics that stuff that can happen later if doing lots of little bits of work many times you could over yield maybe if youre iterating over a large array you dont want to have your yield statement in that array because there is a little bit of a overhead to seed control and then take it back and that could add up instead what you want to do is kind of keep track of how long youve been in the loop yield only if its time to paint another frame so tasks should be kept to under 50 milliseconds and if youre a speed freak and you need to keep you know a 60 frame rate 60 fps frame rate then 16 milliseconds is going to be your budget so if youre looking to yield there are a couple of apis in the scheduler api called yield and posttask theyre available in chromium based browsers but for everybody else you can just use a simple set timeout and thatll usually do the trick during the presentation delay phase is the browser does all of the required style and layout work to get to the next frame ready to paint so number six is avoiding recurring or in avoid incurring large rendering updates however its possible to incur expensive rendering work during the processing phase when its forced by javascript code so youve probably heard this referred to as layout thrashing it happens when you modify a dom element in one part of your code and then you try measuring it in a new part of your code this forces the browser to recalculate all of the styles that are necessary to measure that element and that takes time layout thrashing specifically refers to doing this lots and lots of times over lots of elements causing a chain of expensive rendering work that blocks the main thread so you can break that chain by reorganizing your code so that your read operations happen before you modify the dom and then any necessary style recalculation work can happen normally during that presentation phase routine rendering updates do normally occur during the presentation phase and there are also some things that you can do to minimize that time the first is to reduce the number of affected nodes that need to be repainted for example changing the class list on the body could invalidate the styles for all of the child elements on the page and that could be made even more expensive if you have expensive css selectors that take the browser a long time to figure out if a specific node is going to be affected by that change so to mitigate this you could simplify the selectors but the most effective thing is just to be to minimize the number of dom elements on the page itself that leads to fewer elements to check and also faster style recalculation times another way to minimize rendering time is to lazily render contents that are off the screen using something called css containment the content visibility property just landed in firefox earlier this year so now it is available across all modern browsers you can configure it to tell browsers to skip an elements layout style and paint work if its not visible to the user and then when the element starts to come into view the browser can then resume its rendering work just in time all right the last metric is cumulative layout shift its the best performing core web vital on the wild in the wild and also arguably the most straightforward to optimize it is kind of a strange performance metric in that its not measured in terms of time it doesnt have any units at all and as a matter of fact we dont use it to uh we dont have any phases to break it down because its unitless so for that reason were just going to jump straight into the ways to optimize it with number seven reserving space for content by explicitly setting its dimensions so for an image element you should know how big its going to be and set its height and width accordingly otherwise if if uh the image has an initial height of zero pixels while the browser is waiting for it to load once that pops in thats going to shift the layout down causing a jarring user experience if you at least know what shape the content is going to be you can use the aspect ratio property in css and then you can dynamically size the content and in the worst case scenario if you have no idea whats about to happen you can at least reserve a little bit of space using the min height or minwidth attributes there might still be a noticeable shift but at least it wont be as severe this one might come as a surprise but number eight is uh actually to take advantage of the bf cache which weve already talked about as an lcp optimization the reason why this is a game changer for cls is because a significant amount of the layout shifts that happen actually occur during the initial page load so when you restore a page thats already been loaded and already been rendered any of those layout shifts will have already happened and so the new page view will appear much more stable but today the biggest blockers to bfc eligibility are uh listening to the unload event and also serving html resources with the cache control no store header so finally number nine is to optimize cls by avoiding layout inducing css properties in animations and transitions so for example if you want to slide a piece of content down you might be tempted to animate its down property but even if the content is on its own layer changing the property actually triggers layout work the other directional properties like up left and right behave exactly the same way and the solution to this is use css properties that are animated by the compositor thread instead that means using things like transform translate why to move things and these types of animations do not incur any layout shifts all right weve covered the core web vitals themselves so id like to use whatever remaining time i have to talk about the data that goes behind it i think most of you are familiar with the chrome user experience report or krux data set but i did want to highlight one really important distinction crux powers chrome and search tools like page speit insights dev tools search console its chromes source of truth for how fast or slow users are experiencing core web vitals its an incredibly powerful data set but the kinds of questions that its designed to answer are actually pretty simple like do 75 of the experiences meet the good threshold yes or no how about this metric or this form factor or this page its not designed to answer the second most important question which is okay so why was it slow for that you need diagnostic tools lighthouse is a diagnostic tool and it can point you in the right direction but it cant tell you why your userss experiences were slow it doesnt know how users access or behave on the page and it doesnt know what their lcp elements tend to be but these are all things that you can measure yourselves and the name for that is real user measurement or rum this is something that each site will need to instrument themselves using a commercial rum product uh assuming they have core web vital support or some kind of homegrown solution but the data is worth its weight in gold because you can use it to understand why things are slow and how to reproduce them data is also really hard to argue with um you might recommend to a client that they should uh consider cleaning up some of their marketing tags uh the push back usually sounds something like but we need those well then you can come back to them with data to say uh such and such a tag typically adds 250 milliseconds to every click on the page and its robbing you of a good inpp score well maybe they chang their mind the other thing thats great about rum data is that you can measure the impact of your changes ideally with something like an ab test but even just watching the change over time is really really great uh krux data moves very slowly its a 28 day aggregation but rum data on the other hand you can slice it any way you want uh and when you correlate that with other business business metrics in your analytics you can paint a really compelling picture about the impact that youre having and how valuable your work is just to give you idea of whats possible and this is using all free google tools this is a dashboard that i built to diagnose inp issues on our webdev website it uses the attribution build of the open source web vitals js library to measure the user experiences and get diagnostic data about it i send that off to google analytics using custom events i process all of that data on big query and i visualize it in looker studio so for example i can use this data to track inp performance across the entire site or groups of pages i plot it out over time or as a full distribution and i can drill down into the most popular and problematic areas in this case it looks like the learn pages are especially slow so i can explore the inp phases to see where the time is spent and what is causing it to be slow i know its hard to draw any kind of conclusion from this at a glance but uh this data did help me understand that there was something other than script processing time that was slowing down interactions the input and presentation delay phases were much slower so i dug deeper into what users were interacting with and when i found that the most common interactions were kind of confusing users were just clicking on text uh thats not very interactive but something was still causing that to be slow so the dashboard gave me all of the information i needed to build a reproducible test case so i could figure it out locally in dev tools so i loaded up the page i started to trace i clicked on the heading text and heres what i found and just like in the rum data there was a relatively quick processing duration with those long whiskers extending outward indicating a slow input delay and presentation delay phases there seemed to be a lot of expensive style recalculation work happening and dev tools helped me trace it back to animating spinners i hope this video loads yes so i thought that was really weird because i didnt see any spinners on the page but sure enough they were still there animating away in fact i found 31 spinner components on the page all stuck in an infinite loop and the problem was that despite being hidden hidden the animations were not paused pausing the animations was a simple enough fix so we pushed it live and we immediately saw a 25 improvement to our mobile imp across the learn pages so we still have more work to do getting our inp closer to the green but we are making progress and it wouldnt be possible without rum data to to guide the way so while its true that all of you in the seo community are focused on succeeding in search were still very closely aligned with our goals with the web performance community to improve core web vitals i hope i was able to show you that web performance i hope was able to show you web performance in a slightly different light uh and also how your work to improve core web vitals improves the speed of the web as a whole i also hope that you take these things that youve learned about core web vital metrics and the most effective ways to diagnose and optimize them and you do what you do best share it with the community and apply it in practice to help make an even faster web thank applause you g i more time applause

metadata.speaker: Rachel Anderson

content.raw_text: all right thanks for letting us sort through AV issues and I guess uh give a round of applause for these guys uh figuring this all out I've been behind that and it's not fun it's very stressful all right so yeah I'm the senior SEO manager at weed maps I've been there for a couple of years and previously worked at a bunch of agencies um including in-house at Deep crawl where I worked on the Professional Service profession Services team working with all kinds of large clients like car gurus artsy Etc um I'm excited this is my first inperson conference because I started speaking during the pandemic and they were all cancelled and made virtual so it's really nice to feel the energy of this space all right so what does this mean basically I uh listen to a lot of great presentations about how to build a business case for engineering product and designed resources for SEO projects again I came from agencies I was like okay I'm tucked into marketing at this org I can't get anything done how do I build this business case and I watched a lot of great presentations and I had a lot of assumptions going in I was like okay we were going to get these resources and we're going to immediately start getting progress on all these new initiatives yes we have years of tech Deb to work through we'll do that all first and then we'll be able to start running through with new things uh but the reality is is I quickly realized that all my resources were being eaten up by Tech debt in fact the engineering team I worked with they said we're the janitors of the engineering department here at weed maps we're just cleaning up other people's code all the time and I was like yeah we are this is a huge problem so I asked myself some questions about tech debt versus new features and where our time was going I asked myself how many tickets for Tech SEO um like Tech debt tickets were filed in the past quarter how many Sprint points went to Tech debt versus new features in the last quarter and how many new features for SEO were released on schedule and the answers were appalling we had 30 plus tickets uh that were like net new new problems a third of total Sprint points were being just dedicated towards Tech debt and we could not keep up with it at that level um and none of our projects were released on time uh yeah if you work in house this is probably a common story so I was like okay there's clearly a problem with how we're finding Tech debt um and really our problem was that it was all really reactive so what I'm not saying here is that you don't need to audit uh you absolutely need to audit uh that's why I have site bulb Cloud crawler side note um Gareth and Patrick are great site bulb Cloud crawler is amazing um they did not pay me to say that I paid them for me to say that um so yeah everything we were doing was very reactive uh we were looking at site buold monthly GSC weekly and we were doing manual checks when Engineers thought to pull us in but the problem was all of this code was already visible to search engin so it was already harming us before we would even see it and that's how we ended up with situations like this anyone want to guess y our traffic did that no so we rolled out new product category pages and it didn't go great um the team did not ask for good SEO input uh and the input they gave or we gave they ignored that was when Google started crawling the page from Houston this is what the page looked like and so what would happen cannabis is heavily regionalized and so Google went from crawling in Michigan to crawling in Houston and so they went from a page that had products in it to a page with no products in it and they said oh this is a soft 404 and they took it out of the index and so this cycle just kept happening again and again and again um the thing about cannabis is it is heavily regionalized so because it's federally illegal that means you cannot cross state borders with it and so if I own a cannabis business in California I sell gummies and hey New York has gone wrecked legal I want to start selling the gummies there I can't just you know do a a distribution agreement like we do with beer um I'm from Richmond so we have the veil and now you can get the veil beer other places yay you can't do that with weed no I've got to go I've got to set up my own growroom operation in New York that's probably going to take a year to get any sort of quality product I then have to have all my industrial equipment to create the gummies there in New York and then I have to change all my packaging and maybe quantities to comply with local laws and so it's really really regionalized and Engineers really didn't think about that neither did product when they were putting together the website weed map started out as a directory based website and has moved over towards Ecommerce and so the marketplace being regionalized and having to comply with different laws causes a lot of issues but there were really no QA checks in place for things like this so that's why the traffic is all over the place why we have a roller coaster on this page um and this is being fixed but this is a great uh an issue to highlight the fact that like all projects at the org were having these kinds of problems so we had these dedicated resources they were all being eaten up by SEO regressions so Tech Deb's always going to be a problem so I said hey how can we reduce this negative impact and actually start working on new features to gain traffic and the solution is moving to a more proactive method so we rolled out this four-prong solution to reduce Tech debt so adding um automated test to our cicd pipeline adding SEO sign off in business processes adding SEO QA for high-risk tickets and then finally engineering education I'm going to walk you through these things so part one or part A cicd automated test what is cicd uh it stands for continuous integration and continuous deliver Y and essentially it allows Engineers to constantly be deploying code you're not waiting until 3:00 p.m. on Thursday to release all your tickets if you work for a large org they're working on thousands of tickets each week so you want to make sure that all that code is being released to the website of course the critical component here is that they're checking for bugs before it goes to your production environment so some questions you might want to ask yourself does your organization have this if you work a large tech company inhouse the answer is likely yes um and does your company have automated test not for SEO unless you configured them yourself and are working on maintaining them uh when we started working with our QE team they were like oh we should check canonical tag shouldn't we yeah yeah you should uh so how do you configure it like I just mentioned we had to work with our QA and QE team on this and there are some vendors like deep crawl who have special tools for this but I would recommend checking with your own teams first because these tools are limited to the tests that they'll like that they can run they cost money it takes time to get them integrated in your systems and if you work for a large company you know how long procurement takes so I worked with the QE team and what we did is we outlined all kinds of test that we wanted to set up we listed out all our web surfaces and example URLs that was pretty easy because we just took our keyword mapping information we checked uh we made a list of all the critical HTML elements that we wanted to check for errors and then we talked about um other special things by Page type and then finally Regional tests are very very important and that really was not something that QE had set up initially so we added a lot of regionalized tests in there too so we're checking from Houston Michigan from uh LA from New York City all the markets that really matter for uh cannabis and we use playright for our QE test at weed maps and so this is where we set this up we met weekly with our QE Engineers on configuring these and uh I actually staffed for this so I have a full-time Tech SEO on my team he was responsible for creating these initial tests um fantastic and then maintaining them so um these are living documents they're checking code on the site and so so if you go and update your title tag across a template you need to make sure your test remembers that or else obviously it's going to flag an error so that that's one thing it's stopping bad code from making it to the website very good what this doesn't do is keep Engineers from spending time building bad code that won't work for googlebot so we started working with our product development process to get more buyin so uh typically the business process is kind of look something like this there's a business requirements development phase where you have to get approvals to make sure that the project you're proposing meets business goals if that works you move into the product requirement development phase where you actually outline everything that you need for that project once that happens design and Engineering happens and then finally you go to market so what areas does SEO need to be involved in I would say at least these three and in other cases you may be providing data for the business requirements development section so our PRD phase was a hot mess it was super vague every PM was making different templates for it uh they weren't even outlining like which URLs were being affected and so we would get to the go to market phase and I'd be like whoa whoa whoa you just introduced 50,000 new parameters we can't do that uh and so it would cause thrash at the end of projects uh and it was also a problem for other teams too Le goal uh Revenue they'd be like hey you didn't ask us about this feature this is not going to work for how we make money so we totally overdid the uh PRD requirements phas so there's a template it has all relevant information for stakeholders including things like this Google bot user story and acceptance criteria so this is a part of every single one of our web based projects it just says Hey unless the project specifically tells you to change these things do not touch them uh and you notice facets and filters is there because that's a that's a big one for my company uh so I metadata.title: Getting Technical SEO Work Done at Fortune 100 Companies
metadata.speaker: Kevin Indig

content.raw_text: [Applause] all right it's awesome great to see you all um for me this is a little bit personal because in 2018 uh I spoke at a conference called Tech SEO boost uh put up by Paul ch and the team uh and that said a lot of things in motion for me for my career and personally uh and I'll never forget how um Russ Jones uh rest in peace uh he he he has a very very provocative respectful and nice question at the end of my talk and it just set in motion so many new thoughts and Concepts and so there's a lot to learn here uh and again I I look back six years ago uh and now I'm here so this is somewhat personal for me um that being said welcome to the SEO ship show not to be confused with the SEO show that's going on lots of places but the SEO ship show as in getting things shipped and I want to start with a very quick meditation I want you all to close your eyes also the people streaming from YouTube and I want you to imagine the company that you work for or your client I want you to imagine that you get all of your recommendations sh shipped so everything you suggest everything recommend actually gets done and you learn from that and you beat your competitors and you come up with even better recommendations you're having impact and eventually you're getting promoted now I want you to close your eyes because that's usually not reality that's not what actually happens most of our stuff does not get shipped actually by show of hands raise your hands if more than half of your recommendations get out the door all right I I'll I'll just say that's 5 to 10% lucky you uh I asked the same thing to my uh Twitter followers and here um the picture is somewhat similar so actually less than 50% of recommendations get shipped half of the time so what that means is for 50% of people they only they ship 50% of less or less of what they actually recommend that's a lot of wasted work uh and that's a bit that's a big problem because if you think about it the best technical SEO trick or hack does not matter if it doesn't get implemented it's just vanity right so no shipping means no impact no impact means no purpose no purpose means no job it sounds very harsh but it's true at the end of the day we need to get things out of the door and that's my goal with this presentation is to help you ship recommendations instead of seeing them die in the backlog there's also number one question that I get from um the people that I engage with whether it's at conferences or uh newsletter subscribers um they all want to understand okay how do I get executive Buy in to get my stuff out of the door um Mike mentioned I had the privilege to to work for some incredible companies um and I'm not saying that toag maybe a little bit toag because I crave your approval um but the point is I'm not the most technical person here in the room by far there's a lot that I'm jealous of when it comes to Mike for example um I'm not the the best data person here in the room but one thing that had allowed me to progress in my career is that I get done I get out of the door and it's a skill set that I think is absolutely crucial and complimentary to your technical skills and so that's why today I want to share three contrasts with you that I have so to say learned over the last 12 13 14 years and the first one is the contrast between St Story versus database pitching it is um goal versus work and it is shallo versus deep recommendations so to jump in um story based pitching so everybody wants to be data driven we all like to say that we're data driven about ourselves however that's not always how goes it reminds me um on my time at Shopify so when I when I joined Shopify in 2020 um and we had a world class team we had world class tooling and for me it was kind of a a dream come true because For the First time ever did I work with SC data scientists and engineers and and and lots of smart people and we're able to project the impact of our recommendations maybe down to the single digit I was like wow it's amazing we can we can like really wow everyone with this with this refined kind of system that helps us understand the impact of our recommendations and what actually happened was not just crickets when I presented that to leadership but I actually got a lot of push back we got stuck in these conversations about the math and the methodology and how did we actually get to this number and why is it so precise and once we took a step back and actually like actually not rounded to the single digit but kept the projections a bit more high level but tied them to the mission and to the situation of the company all of a sudden things started flowing and things started moving so you can be too specific when it comes to data and the reality is that that's not always what works because the common assumption here is that Executives you know you can just they just need to see the right data or the right math formula and then they'll say yes to whatever you suggest the reality though is that we're much more driven by emotions and stories than we like to acknowledge as a matter of fact 95% % of all cognition occurs in the subconscious mind and what that means is that we make most decisions based on feelings whether we like to admit it or not so the White story is important um at the same time there's some data suggesting that almost half of Executives um rely much more on Instinct than facts and figures when running their business right which means that people are biased and if if their bias doesn't match the data you present it's really hard to convince people Okay Kevin so how do you get this right I want to give you three tips for getting bu in that is more story based and the first one is to actually tie your recommendation to the company situation a lot of people miss this right A lot of people will go out and they run they start screaming frog or some sort of crawler jet octopus they look at the data right they see some things that don't look right and they present it upwards but they completely miss the overall context and so the context can be for example an acceleration so are going really well um and and you just need to accelerate that Trend and of course there's the other reverse situation as well where oh this looks great uh this is basically time on the uh x-axis um but there's the other situation as well where you we need to turn things around right and that means you need a very different mindset with your recommendations and so there is a framework called Stars it's an acronym that describes the five different situations that we can find ourselves in um and that we can use to to make suggestions recommendations accordingly by the way I'll share the slides feel free take pictures just want to let you know if you cannot see this well uh you'll get the slides you get the recordings Etc um so five situations uh one is startup right so you get something new off the ground then there's the turnaround where you need to maybe save the business um there's accelerating growth which I showed earlier right things are going really well you just need to keep that that momentum going there's a situation of realignment where um you know things had been going but maybe are falling off you need to re-energize the team uh and then they're sustaining success where essentially don't f it up that's kind of the the situation that you're in but just knowing that allows you to speak to leadership in a very very different context and maybe prioritize different recommendations right if you're in a uh sustained success situation for example maybe you want to try some more daring things some more long-term projects whereas if you're in a Turner situation you tell leadership that this might not see uh Roi within you know before a year that's not going to land very well number two there are three things that leaders really care about and that is money market and exposure so essentially things like Revenue profit uh market share and risk and so any recommendation that you give needs to letter up to one of these three things that people care about but it's not just about the the gains here it's also about the stakes so a big mistake that I see that I made early on in my career was that it didn't focus on what's at risk here if we don't do these things I only focused on hey what can we get when we do these things but reality is that people care much more about minimizing risk than maximizing upside and so the the winning formula here is not just your point of view or the recommendation but also combining that with whatever is at risk if that doesn't happen number three um you want to make it personal so at Shopify I learned this this what was new to me at the time thing called back channeling where essentially you you have before you give a big presentation you actually meet with the leaders the decision makers one-onone and maybe you share some of the things you already want to present you get some of their feedback so they're not seeing it for the first time when it's in front of a big group and you can learn about some of their hesitations maybe some of their counter or pro- arguments you can maybe even persuade them you can learn about their optim their individual goals so what are they optimizing for what is their perspective right especially fruitful when it comes to engineering teams or design teams with you might which you might need to implement stuff and number three is the wording so this is very subtle but if you actually use the wording that from from from leaders or from decision makers that can really help you make them feel like they contributed so I I met with people as I I listen to how they call certain things and then I use that exact wording in my presentations so they saw themselves in that presentation and in that plan okay that's number one number two starting with the goal way too often we get very wrapped up and very excited about technical details uh and leaders are usually very overwhelmed by this so I was like that actually early on in my career uh I I I was proud of the length of my uh audits I turned around every diff tag I got super deep Long catalog of things that companies could do and that served me really well when I was a consultant on the agency side and then I went in house and I realized uh okay none of my stuff gets really executed right you get like a lot of Applause when you present these long cataloges but then nobody cares afterwards and only when I started to to call out what are the three things that we need to get done right now toning it down to just three things I actually saw some momentum and traction so the content.raw_text: [Applause] cool thanks everyone uh yes so rolling your own rake tracking solution uh I'll just skip this uh you guys heard about me already um cool so what is the problem with most rank tracking Solutions today you run into the issue that pretty much you're you're locked into this this big platform with its own data um doesn't allow for a lot of customizability you need a you need a new feature um and you're sort of like locked into that you need to go to a different vendor if you need a different feature or you get them to create it which is unlikely um all the data exists in silos for the most part you are um you're getting ring tracking data you may like export it or dump that to a SQL database is and like maybe you want to do an analysis you're you're exporting it doing the analysis there it's not fully baked into the platform unless the the platform made it uh that that analysis ready available for you so there's some clear advantages to running your own rank tracking software like Ranken Berry so you get full data control um everything sits within one platform you all your data that you're going to use for analysis all the rank tracking data anything else that you're pulling in that you want to mix with that data it's all available all in one for you to use end to end um if some a feature doesn't exist you want that feature it's uh you can make it yourself um again you don't have to switch to a different data provider or a different rank tracking software you can go ahead and just add on that functionality if you need it um lastly Rank and Barry is an open-source project which means uh Beyond this being a oneman show um if you want to contribute and help others you're surely able to do that so to get started it's a like I said it's an open source project it's available on a GitHub repo feel free to clone that repo and run it yourself or contribute to it um whatever you want it's up to you um I'll just put this front first is uh right now it's running off of a rank tracking API called space serp which has this lifetime deal on appsumo it's started as the API first before I decided to build a rank tracker that's that's the Genesis of this I got a really good deal on a rank tracking API and I built software around it um but if you want to actually try the project you will need access to space serp first it's like 60 bucks for life it's not bad um cool so talking about the the architecture of rank and Berry oh before I do this um let me just say uh I had this really ambitious road map for Ranken Barry like I
